results.title: Tales from other worlds
results.creator_credit: Robin Bates, National Academy of Sciences (U.S.) and WQED
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Planet earth”.
Voyages to other planets have shown us that earth is unique. The question now is why? Through the use of little-seen footage shot in space, this program attempts to answer questions such as why there is no life on Mars and Venus, why the dinosaurs disappeared, whether earth has been bombarded by meteorites in the past. A fascinating look at the formation of the planets.

results.title: The Coast: a question of balance
results.creator_credit: David Hughes, Dept of the Navy and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: Filmed on location at Mornington Peninsula, Bellarine Peninsula, Apollo Bay, Torquay, Westernport Bay and Port Melbourne, this film is designed to alert students to the conflict inherent in man’s use of the coastal system, potentially one of the most fragile of environments. Shows the abuse of the sand dune systems through leisure, sport, traffic and the erection of structures, as well as the heavy demands placed by industry and shipping on coastal waters. Stresses that these competing interests will, if left unchecked, ultimately destroy the delicate flora and fauna balance of the coastal system. Music performed by Pink Floyd - “Be careful with that axe, Eugene” Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: The Classical idea
results.creator_credit: Bayley Silleck and Educational Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Art of the western world”.
An episode in the comprehensive art history series, “Art of the Western World”, that focuses on the art of the Western classical world. Narrated by Michael Wood, this program focuses on the origins of humanism and classical works of ancient Greece as well as Roman architecture and engineering. Through a discussion of the works in their historical, religious, intellectual and social context, this program provides both a thorough outline of these periods in art history and underlines their relevance to issues outside the parameters of the works themselves.

results.title: The Cleo Laine collection
results.creator_credit: Graeme Rowland, Bill Ramsey and de Montignie Productions
results.brief_description: Recorded live at the Melbourne Concert Hall in 1986, this video presents the sensuous and sultry jazz and blues singer Cleo Laine performing with her husband John Dankworth and the Dankworth Quartet. British born Cleo Laine began her musical career in the early 1950s where she met and married renowned musician John Dankworth in 1958. Together they have toured the world (and still currently touring) but Cleo has also tried her hand at acting on the stage in such plays as “Flesh to a tiger”, “A Midsummer night’s dream” and the title role in Ibsen’s “Hedda Gabler” among many other performances. Songs from this Melbourne concert by this great lady include “Free and easy”, “I love you just the way you are”, “Crazy rhythm”, “Send in the clowns”, “He was beautiful”.

group_works.title: The Chronicles of Narnia [DVD]

results.title: The Chronicles of Narnia [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Alex Kirby, Marilyn Fox, Paul Stone and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Chronicles of Narnia”.
A breathtaking live action, made for television rendition of C. S. Lewis’ powerful fantasy for all ages using stunning special effects to recreate the most exciting and enchanting adventure of them all. “The Lion, the witch and the wardrobe”: four children, sent from London into the countryside during the dangerous period of WW2, discover the magical world of Narnia - where dwarves, nymphs and giants reside, fauns carry umbrellas, animals talk and horses fly. It is also the land of Aslan, the great lion who can warm the coldest heart and his arch-enemy, the White Witch. “Prince Caspian”: Troubled times have come to Narnia and the evil King Miraz and his scheming Queen Prunaprismia have brought misery and an army of destruction to the peaceful land. Young Prince Caspian, rightful heir to the throne vows to save his kingdom and calls upon the aid of Peter, Susan, Edmund and Lucy. “The Voyage of the dawn treader”: A new quest begins for Edmund and Lucy, who, with their horrible cousin Eustace, join King Caspian on a voyage to find seven missing Lords of Narnia. The Silver chair Old King Caspian’s only son and heir, Prince Rillian has disappeared. The great lion, Aslan, calls on Jill and Eustace, guiding them in their search for the lost prince. On their perilous quest, the children meet up with Puddleglum who travels with them to the land of giants. Their search leads them to face the Green Witch, the Queen of the Deep Realm whose spell they must break. Each edition also available separately on VHS [301499], [301990], [302722].

results.title: Penitentiary
results.creator_credit: Ronald Weyman, Sydney Newman and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Canada carries on”.
A report on life and conditions in one of Canada’s penal institutions, illustrating current trends in the treatment of criminals. Defiant and contemptuous of society, a young first offender is brought to a federal penitentiary. The film shows the descipline, the confinement and the rigid routines which are part of a prisoner’s expiation for crime. It also deals with the challenge, now recognized by penitentiary authorities - either to change the prisoner into a law-abiding citizen or to have them come back a repeater - and with the new psychological approach which endeavours to determine the basic causes of a person’s wrong-doing.
